Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is in the area of high quality capacitor solution to replace the bulky and lossy aluminum electrolyte capacitors (AECs), a ubiquitous circuit element used in power systems and electronics for current ripple filtering, decoupling, and pulse charging/discharging, among other purposes. Rising demand for high quality capacitors is driven by automotive, telecom, medical and commercial electronics, and by the rapid growth of process automation and internet of things (IoT) in the industrial sectors. The widely used AECs have a low volumetric capacitance density and high parasitic resistance. Their bulky size and high resistive loss limits the system size and performance. Therefore, developing new technologies of quality capacitors will have the opportunities to greatly improve the system performance. These systems and applications span from inverters and DC power suppliers for industry machines, electronic appliances and medical devices, mini and low-profile circuit boards, to efficient storage of the pulse energy harvested from the environmental mechanical vibration, motion, and noise, as well as high-frequency high-power pulse generators.

This I-Corps project will explore the market potential of high-frequency AC supercapacitor technology for current ripple filtering in AC/DC conversion and for pulse energy storage in environmental energy harvesting. These supercapacitors based on the principle of electric double layer capacitance and therefore provide a very large capacitance density. However, unlike conventional double layer capacitors that can only be charged-discharged below a frequency of 1 Hz, the devices developed here run at hundreds to kilo-hertz high frequencies and therefore suitable for ripple current filtering and pulse energy storage and generation. The high-frequency characteristic of the device is achieved via nano-engineered carbon fiber and graphene electrodes with suitable pore sizes. This I-Corps project will evaluate the market opportunity of the AC supercapacitor technology through customer discovery interviews. The feedback from these activities will provide better understanding on the customer needs and commercialization requirements, and therefore drive the technology development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project is to find out the possibility of commercializing the high-frequency supercapacitor (AC-SupercapTM) technology for current ripple filtering used in all AC/DC power conversion and electronic circuits, as well as for pulse power generation.

During this NSF I-CORPS program, the team developed a business model canvas and a business plan for commercialization of the AC-SupercapTM technology. A PCT patent application was filed in April 2018 following prior disclosure to Texas Tech University in 2017. A business team was built to develop the products for commercialization. Federal grant (NSF STTR phase I) and other funds from Texas Tech University and local community were secured for technology development and prototyping.

In this project, the team interviewed more than 150 potential customers in the electronics and power industries across the United States, including design and product engineers, sales representatives, department managers, up to the business presidents and CEOs, as well as the end users. Through these interviews, the team learned the capacitor overall markets and several segments this technology was planned to target, and the market developing trends. The team particularly focused on customers’ needs on AC-filtering capacitors, their pain points when employing the current solutions and their desired features and improvements if new products could be provided. The team acquired knowledge on market segments including AC-filtering capacitors, pulse power sources, and those applications such as downhole drilling, outdoor electronics, renewable energy and LED lightings, among others, which have extreme demands on capacitor reliability under harsh environments. The team researched the total addressable market (TAM) for commercial capacitor application, and the serviceable available market (SAM) size. The team obtained understanding on the capacitor industry, the value chain, and the position the team targets at in this value chain. The team learned the different sales channels in the capacitor market, from direct and OEM channels, sale representatives to retailers, and different pricing strategies. All these and other unlisted knowledge acquired from this I-Corps project are helping the team develop business plan for commercialization of this technology.        

The team assessed the collected information from customer interview and market research. The team decide to GO with the formation of a new team by including new members to further develop the technology. With better knowledge on the customers’ need and market developing trends, the team refined the product features with three product series in meeting the slightly different requirements of three major groups of applications/customers. Based on the results of this I-Corps project and the greater clarity of the business model and business plan achieved, a proposal was submitted to the NSF STTR Phase I program, which proved to be successful and technology development is under way toward commercialization.

Capacitors are an essential component used in any electronic devices, in power supplies driving any electrical machines, appliances and instruments, as well as in power conversion and condition systems used for solar, wind and other renewable energy generation. Our innovative new capacitor, AC-Supercap™, with its much better performance than current solutions, is anticipated to better serve the needs of many customers. AC-SupercapTM innovation was initially developed in NSF-funded fundamental research at Texas Tech University. Commercialization of such a research outcome is aligned with NSF missions. Located in the high-tech deficient West Texas, the success of the commercialization effort of this team from Texas Tech will also have impact on the local ecosystem and community, as a synergy will be built upon this success. During and after this project, the team has encouraged several teams participating the NSF I-CORPS program. In the end, the I-Corps program has radically impacted the entrepreneurial education of the team, including the PI and newly graduated students. 

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2019
Modified by: Zhaoyang Fan
